bibl.title: Letter from [S.C. Mead] to Daniel R. Anthony, June 20, 1922

div1.p: [Mead] writes to Congressman Anthony in support of the continuation of Mabel Lazear's annuity.

div1.head: Letter from [S.C. Mead] to Daniel R. Anthony, June 20, 1922
div1.opener:
June 20, 1922.
Honorable Daniel R. Anthony, Jr., Chairman,
Subcommittee of Committee on Appropriations,
House of Representatives,
Washington, D. C.
Dear Sir:
div1.p:
We have just learned that in the preparation of the War
Department Appropriation Bill your Committee is very properly seeking
information concerning the annuity which was granted by Congress in
1908 to Mrs. Mabel H. Lazear at the same time that a similar annuity
was granted to Mrs. Jennie H. Carroll.

It so happens that The Merchants' Association of New York
took leadership in urging Congress at that time to grant these annu-
ities, in which movement commercial organizations of the country generally,
particularly those located on the Atlantic and Pacific seaboards and
the Gulf of Mexico, and the American Medical Association actively co-
operated.

The purpose of this letter is to give you and your Committee
exact information as to the reasons which impelled the Association to
Hon. Daniel R. Anthony, Jr., Chairman
#2
urge that action at that time, which reasons we feel are equally op-
erative today as then.

Doctor Jesse W. Lazear, as well as Major James Carroll, was
a member of the so-called Yellow Fever Commission, which undertook to
determine the method of transmission and propagation of yellow fever
germs to the end that determination of the cause and method of trans-
mission might provide information upon which effective prevention of
that scourge could be determined and applied. Many tests were made
by the members of that Commission, including among others the volun-
tary submission by Doctor Lazear and Major Carroll to the bite of the
mosquito, which was suspected to be the germ carrier. As a result of
such submission to inoculation by the mosquito these two men actually
contracted yellow fever, which voluntary act in the service of humanity
resulted finally in the death of these two men. The self-sacrifice,
however, proved the case and provided the basis of knowledge upon which
it has been possible to prevent any serious yellow fever scourge in
this or other countries since that time.

Because of this sacrifice of service on the part of those two
men, which resulted not merely in the elimination of suffering and death
from yellow fever but also in service of incalculable value to the
business of the United States engaged in trade and commerce, this Asso-
ciation advocated that the widows of these two gentlemen should be ap-
propriately recognized by an annuity granted by Congress.

The Association's investigation at that time proved that
Doctor Lazear and Major Carroll, by their death, left their families
without adequate means of support. That fact was emphasized by
Brigadier-General Robert M. O'Reilly, then Surgeon-General of the
Hon. Daniel R. Anthony, Jr., Chairman
#3
United States, in his Memorandum to Honorable Theodore Roosevelt,
President of the United States, urging fitting recognition of the im-
portant service of these two members of the Yellow Fever Commission.
The facts presented by the Surgeon-General so appealed to President
Roosevelt that the latter transmitted the Memorandum to Congress with
his favorable endorsement.

Later, the propriety of such action was again emphasized, in
the passage, by unanimous vote of the United States Senate and the
House of Representatives, of the necessary legislation, in response to
the desire for such recognition expressed by every section of the country,
when the financial status of the families of Doctor Lazear and Major
Carroll became known, especially as other members of the Yellow Fever
Commission were appropriately taken care of.

What change, if any, has taken place since 1908 in the fi-
nancial resources of either of these two ladies we do not know. We
understand, however, that in the case of Mrs. Lazear, at least, she is
still entirely dependent upon the annuity granted by Congress in 1908.
If this is the fact, we respectfully submit that the causes which not
only justified but as a matter of justice required the granting of the
annuity in 1908 still continue in full effect and we therefore urge
upon your Committee that the annuities be continued in recognition of
the enormous service to mankind as well as to business, in the rendering
of which these two men sacrifice their lives.
div1.closer:
Yours very truly, THE MERCHANTS' ASSOCIATION OF NEW YORK,
By
Secretary. SB
